Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The effect of sand fraction and event evolution on fine-sediment transport and the depositional record in wave-supported mud flows
Award.AbstractNarration:
Part 1
Offshore delivery of fine sediment on the continental shelf via wave supported gravity currents (WSGC) is a key component of sediment transport fromsource to sink, yet it remains poorly understood. Current models of this process focus on suspension and transport of silt and clay sized particles. However, recent laboratory experiments show that even a small amount of sand in the sediment layer may exert a dominant control on the dynamics of the transport layer. The proposed effort will investigate the effect of sand fraction on sediment transport in WSGC, particularly, the transition between transport modes, the downslope transport and the depositional signatures. The objectives will be addressed using a comprehensive series of laboratory experiments, 3D turbulence-resolving numerical simulations, and re-analysis of existing field data from WSGC on active continental margins. The work is relevant to a broad range of fields, from fluid mechanics and water resource engineering, to studies of biogeochemical cycles. Outreach include introduction of the relevance of sedimentary processes to K-12 students with hand-on experiments in the university labs, and invited presentations to local schools. Undergraduate and graduate students will be involved. In addition to journal papers and conference presentations, open-source codes will be disseminated through Community Surface Dynamics Modeling System (CSDMS) framework.

Part 2
Offshore delivery of fine sediment on the continental shelf via wave supported gravity currents (WSGC) is a key component of sediment source to sink, yet it remains poorly understood. Current models of this process focus on suspension and transport of silt and clay sized particles. However, recent laboratory experiments show that even a small amount of sand in the sediment layer may exert a dominant control on the dynamics of the transport layer. The proposed effort investigates the effect of sand fraction on sediment transport in WSGC, particularly, the transition between transport modes, the downslope transport and the depositional signatures. The project is formed around two main objectives: 1) Determine the role of the sand fraction in controlling dynamics and transport within WSGC and the bed deposits associated with them. 2) Evaluate impacts of event evolution (surging and waning of a storm) on the sediment and flow dynamics within a gravity flow and the resulting depositional signatures These will be addressed using a comprehensive series of laboratory experiments, 3D turbulence-resolving numerical simulations, and re-analysis of existing field data from WSGC on active continental margins. The work is relevant to a broad range of fields, from fluid mechanics and water resource engineering, to studies of biogeochemical cycles. Outreach include introduction of the relevance of sedimentary processes to K-12 students with hand-on experiments in the university labs, and invited presentations to local schools. Undergraduate and graduate students will be involved. In addition to journal papers and conference presentations, open-source codes will be disseminated through Community Surface Dynamics Modeling System (CSDMS) framework.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Marine geologists and scientists have been trying to close a missing link in the ?source-to-sink? description of the lifecycle of sediment, in which sediment is generated in the mountains, carried to the coast, and ultimately lost to the abyssal ocean. Understanding these processes is critical for understanding geochemical cycling (e.g., carbon), ecosystem impacts and coastal resource management. Along continental margins ocean currents flow parallel to the coast, and the slope of the seabed is not sufficiently steep for sediment to be carried to deeper water by gravity alone. Scientists have been trying to understand how sediment from rivers moves across the continental shelf.

 

Field observations suggest that surface gravity waves may play an important role in this process by generating shear stress on the seabed that is large enough maintain a thick high-concentration mud layer in suspension, which will then flow downslope due to gravity. These are referred to as wave-supported gravity currents (WSGC). While observations from a number of field campaigns point to the importance of this process, measurements that would enable detailed predictive models of WSGC are challenging in the field due to the episodic nature of the currents and the fact that they are very thin.

 

Intellectual merit: A key objective of work in this area is to understand what limits the amount of sediment in a WSCG event, which will determine the magnitude of cross-shelf sediment flux. Some models suggest that there is a feedback between the negative buoyancy of the sediment water mixture and the turbulence generated by the flow that ultimately sets the maximum carrying capacity of WSGCs. Others suggest that the erodibility of the seabed is the limiting factor. In prior laboratory experiments we observed that, although WSGCs occurs in predominantly muddy environments, small concentrations of sand in the mixture on the order of only one to fifteen percent appear to have an outsized effect on the dynamics. The goal of this project was to determine how the sand fraction influenced the dynamics of WSGCs and, in particular, how it changed the erodibility or carrying capacity of the flows.

 

We modeled WSGCs in the laboratory using a 9-meter wave-sediment tank, measuring the velocity, turbulence and sediment concentration in significantly higher resolution than is possible in the field and under a controlled set of conditions. We carried out sets of experiments under varying wave conditions and with sediment mixtures with two sand fractions: 1% and 13%. Our results show that the sand fraction influences the flow in two primary ways. First, the sediment bed with a higher (13%) sand fraction generates ripples. This makes the bed rougher, enhancing the turbulence over the bed and increasing the suspension of fine sediment out of the bed. Somewhat surprisingly, the 1% sand fraction also generated ripples; however, they only occurred under the most energetic wave forcing conditions and it took longer for them to form than in the higher sand fraction runs. Second, we found that there is a threshold shear stress necessary to generate a high-concentration sediment layer, which depended on the median size of the sand grains in the mixture instead of the median size of the whole mixture. In other words, the sand fraction, whether it was only 1% or 13% controls the threshold for suspension and, presumably, the initiation of WSGC events.

 

Together the above observations support the conclusion that sand plays a very important role in the dynamics of WSGCs. Furthermore, since sand influences the erodibility of the bed more than the carrying capacity of the flow, we conclude that the former is more important than the latter in determining the magnitude of sediment transported in WSGCs. We tested these results using measurements from field observations in WSGCs off the coast of the Netherlands and New Zealand. The threshold condition observed in the laboratory was successful in predicting the generation of a high concentration layer in the field in both cases, suggesting that this result may have broad applicability for predicting when and where WSGCs can form. Finally, we have worked closely with our colleagues at the University of Delaware who have developed new numerical models of WSGCs that account for the dynamics observed in the laboratory experiments.

 

Broader impacts: This work furthers our understanding of the interplay between turbulence and density stratification, key dynamical elements of many environmental flows. It helps to clarify and develop the physical basis for improving predictive models of a key process on the continental shelf, with implications for carbon budget and coastal ecosystem health. The project supported four PhD students. Our results have been published in nine scientific journal papers and we presented our findings at many national and international conferences. We also communicated our work to the public using outreach activities at the University of Washington?s Discovery Days (K-8 students and their parents).
